Cray, Mackenzie and the Adviser tc the Bahrain Government asking for suggestions to stop the pilfering.No. C/327 The Political Asancy v Bahrain, the 5th March, 1945 From Major T. Kickinbotham, C.I.E., Political Agent, Bahrain. To The Adviser to the Government of Bahrain, Bahrain . Sir, I have the honour to draw your attention to the serious increase in pilfering of merchandise being landed both from the Manama and the Sitra anchorages. 2. I am given to understand that pilfering takes place in the holds of the vessels discharging cargo, when the cargo is being lightened to the shore, and in some cases when the cargo is awaiting discharge from lighters or the opening of the Muharraq causeway bridge. Coolies working cargo appear to be fully aware of the most profitable cases to open for it is generally packages containing expensive goods in great demand on shore, that are tampered with. From statements which have been made to me I believe that infor mation is conveyed to the thieves by intelligent persons who have access to ships' documents prior to the cargo being discharged from the ship or at any rate landed from lighters. 3. It has been apparent to me for some time that consi derable dissatisfaction was being felt both by import merchants and the general public at the very serious losses which are occurring as a result of pilferage between the ship ana the shore. The mercnants who met me as usual today for the weexily conference on trading matters again drew my attention to what is really a very disgraceful state of affairs. One member went -so far as to declare that an official of the shipping company was actually present recently when a case was pilferred and did nothing to protect the property of the clients of his firm. It was also stated by another person present tnat he had recently bean on board a ship and seen coolies and a police man carrying piecegoods away from the vessel without any attempt being made to prevent them. I suggest that/fc time has come when drastic action must be taken to prevent pilfering and to bring those engaged in this nefarious practice to trial. 4. I am sending a copy of this letter to Messrs. Gray Mackenzie and Company with the request that every endeavour be made by them to prevent any leakage of information about cargoes for it is their duty ana chat of their employees to use their best endeavours to protect goods entrusted to them by shippers. I suggest that they should instruct their employees to make an immediate report of any pilfering that may come to their notice. A report on the condition of the cargo in the holds of the s.s. •William 3. The Company pecking list, a copy of which is passed to Cray Mackenzie & Co., showed that the cases contained tickets (without mention of kind) for delivery to the Bahrein Government. The cases were sturdily made but were handed over to us in a broken condition - of one case the whole of the top had been removed and one side plank of the second was smashed. The cases were repaired at the Company Storehouse immediately after checking the contents It is suggested that it may be possible to trace the thieves by marking with a rubber stamp those tickets that are officially Issued so that when unmarked tickets are presented the person presenting nay be held for interrogation. physicalDescription.extent: The papers in the file are arranged chronologically. There are file notes at the end, on folio 18. The notes are arranged chronologically and refer to documents within the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1 and terminates at the back cover with 19; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is also present in parallel between ff 2-18; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled, and are located in the same position as the main sequence.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence between the Political Agent at Bahrain, the manager of Gray Mackenzie & Co, and the Adviser to the Government of Bahrain concerning measures to contrast pilfering of goods from ships.
